awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Nanophotonic Radiative Decay Rate Engineering for Stable Blue Organic Phosphorescence
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description: Display and lighting technologies that use organic light-emitting materials are emerging as energy-efficient, versatile alternatives to liquid-crystal displays and inorganic light-emitting diode (LED)-based lighting. However, high-efficiency blue phosphorescent organic light-emitting devices exhibit operational lifetimes that are 20 to 45 times shorter than green and red organic phosphorescent devices, which limit their commercial use. This project addresses this important technology challenge through fundamental materials science research and employs photonic nanostructures to increase the stability of high-efficiency, blue organic light-emitting materials. In addition, the project involves the public in an interactive public experiment, built by undergraduate and K-12 students, to test the lifetime of light-emitting materials and to stimulate interest in these materials and to enable the findings of the research project to be communicated to audiences beyond the academic community. Graduate and undergraduate researchers working on the research project have opportunities to take part in international research experiences to expand their research skills, foster international scientific collaborations and gain global perspectives of the technical challenges faced by developing countries. 

Technical Description: High-efficiency organic light-emitting devices use either phosphorescent molecules or molecules that exhibit thermally-activated delayed fluorescence to allow radiative recombination from triplet excitons. However, there are stability problems associated with high-efficiency, blue organic triplet-emitting materials primarily due to triplet-triplet and triplet-polaron annihilation, which can occur faster than radiative decay times of triplet exciton emitters at high luminance. The research component of this CAREER award aims to increase the photostability and electroluminescence stability of blue organic triplet emitters by making use of radiative decay rate enhancements caused by the Purcell Effect arising from near-field (i.e., 5-50 nm) interactions between emitters and the local electromagnetic fields of nanophotonic structures. Faster radiative decay rates allow triplet emission to compete with triplet quenching non-radiative pathways and, thereby, improve the stability of the emitting material. Size- and shape-controlled dielectric (e.g., silica, zinc oxide) and passivated plasmonic (silver and aluminum) nanophotonic structures prepared from a range of nanofabrication techniques are employed.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

Display and lighting technologies that use organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs) are emerging as energy-efficient, versatile alternatives to liquid-crystal displays and inorganic light-emitting diode (LED)-based lighting. However, high-efficiency blue phosphorescent OLEDs exhibit operational lifetimes that are 20 to 45 times shorter than green and red organic phosphorescent OLEDs, which limit their commercial use. This project aimed to find solutions to this technology challenge through fundamental materials science research, and employed photonic nanostructures to increase the stability of high-efficiency, blue OLED materials. The project also provided interdisciplinary research training experiences in experimental and theoretical materials science, optics and photonics, nanotechnology and organic semiconductor physics and engineering.

 

Intellectual Merit:

The objectives of this project were to employ extrinsic radiative decay rate engineering to increase the stability of high-efficiency, blue organic phosphorescent materials and, to educate graduate, undergraduate and K-12 students, as well as the public, in next-generation light-emitting materials. We demonstrated surface plasmon enhanced photostability in high-efficiency blue organometallic phosphor thin films by factors of up to 3.6 using plasmonic metasurfaces. A luminance-dependence of the photostability enhancement was also observed. We tested a range of nanophotonic nanostructures and found that nanoparticle-based metasurfaces with responses that spectrally and spatially overlap with the emitting materials are most effective at enhancing photostability.

Broader Impacts:

The project resulted in 15 published, peer-reviewed, scientific journal papers, one book chapter and one issued US patent, as well as 11 contributed conference and seminar presentations by graduate and undergraduate students involved in the project. In addition, 7 invited and keynote presentations were given by the PI on the project work. This project supported and trained 6 graduate, 6 undergraduate and 4 high-school students (10 female, 6 male, 3 underrepresented minorities). Four PhD students that were supported by the project graduated in the 2018 to 2021 timeframe. Education and outreach activities included participation in undergraduate recruiting programs (REU/RiSE, NJ GSET and Project SUPER programs at Rutgers); photonics demonstrations to the public at Rutgers Day and international collaborations and workshops with Trinity College Dublin (Ireland), and Peking University (China).

The demonstrated improvements in the photostability of blue organic phosphors using our extrinsic approach impacts the stability of high-efficiency, blue OLED materials for display and lighting technologies. The approach developed in this project was a new approach to blue OLED stability improvements that has technological relevance. For example, we estimate that if this technology is integrated with existing OLED displays, an improvement in operational stability of more than a factor of three and an energy conversion efficiency increase from <10% to 20% is possible for the blue OLED pixels. This would represent an energy savings to the consumer and prolongue the usable lifetime of portable electronic devices.


Last Modified: 11/10/2022
Modified by: Deirdre M O'carroll
